perturbation.original_text: Termination for Cause Customer or IBM may terminate this Agreement for material breach of this Agreement by the other upon written notice containing the specific nature and dates of the material breach.  The breaching party will have thirty (30) days from receipt of notice to cure such breach, except for nonpayment by Customer, which must be cured within five (5) days from receipt of notice. If such breach has not been timely cured, then the non-breaching party may immediately terminate this Agreement upon written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: Termination for Cause Customer or IBM may terminate this Agreement for material breach of this Agreement by the other upon written notice containing the specific nature and dates of the material breach. The breaching party will have ten (10) days from receipt of notice to cure such breach, except for nonpayment by Customer, which must be cured within two (2) days from receipt of notice. If such breach has not been timely cured, then the non-breaching party may immediately terminate this Agreement upon written notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text gives the breaching party 30 days to cure a material breach and 5 days to cure nonpayment. The modified text reduces this to 10 days and 2 days, respectively, which may be inconsistent with legal standards of reasonable opportunity to cure, especially if the contract is construed under laws that require longer cure periods for certain types of breaches.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles regarding 'reasonable opportunity to cure'. Specific state laws may dictate minimum cure periods for certain breaches.

perturbation.original_text: Actions Period Neither party will bring a legal action related to this Agreement more than two years after the cause of action accrued.
perturbation.changed_text: Actions Period Neither party will bring a legal action related to this Agreement more than one year after the cause of action accrued.
perturbation.explanation: Shortening the statute of limitations to one year is a legal contradiction because the standard statute of limitations for contract disputes is typically longer than one year depending on the state (e.g., 4 years in New York where the contract is governed). This modification potentially violates laws preventing unreasonably short limitations periods.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Varies by state, but in New York, breach of contract has a 6 year Statute of Limitations. Many states have 4 year Statute of limitations

perturbation.original_text: Monthly reports showing service request, resolution, call aging data, and other call report information within ten (10) business days from the end of the calendar month. The reports will be provided via the web portal.
perturbation.changed_text: Monthly reports showing service request, resolution, call aging data, and other call report information within thirty (45) business days from the end of the calendar month. The reports will be provided via email, upon request, subject to a fee of $100 per request.
perturbation.explanation: Increasing the delivery timeframe to 45 business days, and adding a fee, could be considered an unreasonable delay in providing necessary operational information, particularly if timely access to this data is critical for the customer to monitor service quality or ensure compliance. For larger companies, the customer needs this data within a shorter time frame than 45 business days.  Adding a fee to receive the email could be viewed as anti-consumer.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of good faith and fair dealing in contracts. Unreasonable delays or fees in providing essential information may be challenged.
